content: Working on this in PHP.  Can't get more than 6 out of 9 cases nor validators online.  The most expensive part of my code is copying the board $tb=unserialize(serialize($b)); (a full 2 dim board) which is done for example 154,265 times on case 6 - Glass.  If i could fit the biggest board in 63 bits I'm sure i could do it.  Traditionally my depth searches can't go past depth 9, especially with this width - so that tracks with expectations.  I think I can make it better, but for the time expenditure to do so ... it should be hard and worth more xp imo.  there are some tricks to pull off DFS, the overhead of any other alg is too much imo that add undue complexity.  if you scan the board in a diagonal fashion you can pre-setup "fit" placement.  For example, Glass has 715 such total placements over the 9 pieces.  if you have x,y you can clearly see how any cell x+a,y+b is dependent on x,y, so pre-tabling by x,y on diagonals should be efficient.  And if letters are reassigned from largest to smallest pieces IFCEGJLBNDMAKH , the distribution of those letters over all 715 is 88,37,0,58,56,60,56,0,142,0,68,150,0,0 with the first trial as I @ 0,0.  Considering there are multiple possible solutions, reducing the open board space first makes sense.  Bad future moves are easily skipped if a condition like if (($bv|$cv)==$bv) { } isn't satisfied.  However that brings up the second most expensive function, grabbing the mask value from the board... which is called 786,681 times ... again just grabbing 16 bits from a 2d board and comparing to the piece orientation bitset.  Since order of placement doesn't matter, i can see dancing around and hashing compatible and incompatible moves ... but I can't visualize the expense v. savings since moves can be skipped so easily.  I'll try to more linearize the board and adjust the foundational bit twiddling, but I doubt I can solve all 9 online in php.  Since php stores strings more efficiently than arrays i tried changing the mb_internal_encoding, but still requires a conversion step before any comparisons are made.  So while copying less memory each time is more efficient the coding and decoding seems to be still be done at a 7-bit level internally and you lose any speed gains.  A 1dim array of height+4 would be required to streamline the board to its best available format, which i'll try next.  I type too much, but i think limiting the pieces to a total of 9 per case would solve the issue of slow langs.  And thanks for not making it more than 1 piece being possible per case.  yes, coding is fun.  overthinking, not so much.
cool puzzle but my solution passes all tests in ide but fails validator for test 9 (full brick) :(

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Plenty of comments below. I love this contribution! Sure, it's a classic Exact Cover, so maybe I'm biased. Still, @VizGhar has done an absolutely outstanding job putting it together!

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Cool puzzle, the description is clear & you have a nice progression with the tests/validators. The referee seems to be working properly.

Increased time limit to 5s
Added more easy tests to try basics
Tests - Validators now more similar
Removed DFS tag since clear DFS is too hard to pull of
Added Algorithm X tag

Some feedback while I still have not entirely solved it.

I went and frankesteined my ruby solution (~DFS like) to https://www.codingame.com/training/hard/tetris-floor, and:

- I could have used some smaller testcases at the beginning, preferably with starting letters (that is: A, B instead of let's say E, N), to debug the core logic.
- I'm timeoutting on Butterfly and Owl Mask
- I don't find any solutions to Llama (validator) and Dino (validator)
- I pass the rest

From my understanding, the timeout limit is 2 seconds for everyone (as opposed to language dependent limits in I/O puzzles), so I would be very interested to know if someone managed to solve it in python / ruby within that limit (using a DFS-like approach).

Also, the two hardest public tests: Butterfly and Owl Mask, seem to hint at symmetry optimizations that are not relevant for the validators. Maybe there should be more similarity?

print('OOD')
print('AAD')
print('O.O')

I can pass test case #1 with this output. I get a "congratulations" message even though the pieces are not where they belong in the picture.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: An interesting problem with nice graphics. This sets a new standard for exact cover puzzles.

I have mixed feelings about your puzzle: you could have made your life easier (and mine) if you only asked for a grid filled with symbols. It feels a bit over engineered. On the other end, it's very nice to have an animated puzzle.
Outstanding job! Fun to solve and especially fun to watch the tiles fly across and go into position. Being able to visualize the exact cover is super cool!

print("OO;.O;.O")
print("0 1")

Do you need to update your stub output?

Have you considered including multiples? For instance:

ABBBBEFN

Adding multiplicity would make the puzzle more difficult for the exact cover solution.

You don't even necessarily need more pictures. Could a single shape be solved multiple times (multiple test cases), each time with a different group of polyominoes?

Title
* Please change "Polyominos" to "Polyominoes".

Default code
* Please change "polyominos" to "polyominoes".

* Please change "tiles" to "polyominoes" (twice).

* Please change "tile" to "polyomino".

Example
* Please change ". Or" to ",".

While I know it's acceptable to output the placement of more than 1 piece per turn,
â€¢ Doing so actually triggers the "your code did not read all available input" warning.
â€¢ Doing so is inconsistent with Output section, which specifies that only one line should be output per turn.

So, let's do it the same way as Power of Thor: if the player knows the trick and wants to output everything in the first turn, let them do so, but we won't mention the trick in the statement ðŸ˜‰

Input
* Line 1: Please change "polyominos" to "polyominoes".

Output
* Please change "Line" to "1 Line".

* Please format "n", "row" and "column" with the <var> tag. The comma and the brackets will still be formatted with the <const> tag.

* Any reason for having to place the pieces in a specific order? Would it be possible to let the player place the pieces in any order they want (e.g. the output will first specific the id of the piece to place, followed by where to put the piece)?

Tags
* I'm not sure how the tag "Flood fill" is relevantâ€¦?

Thanks.
Game is ready

Your notes are resolved now.

Placing pieces in specific order is meant to force player to output just single line per turn and it's a little bit easier to handle on referee side. I've added paragraph in "The Goal" section to add a little bit to story = dont make your little brother angry.

Edit: small changes in wording + added link to github repo. Nothing crucial

Yeah forgot update stub.
Not sure if multiplicity will be more difficult. I could just set the polyomino ID to B0, B1... internally
5DN1L also wanted to fill board in single turn. I'll pull the puzzle to WIP until resolved. Thank for input

I also get congratulations for this on test case 2 even though one piece is well off the board and letters are messed up:

print('..L..')
print('AABBB')
print('A.C.L')
print('ACCCJ')
print('H.C.J')
print('HHJJJ')

I figured out why I was not finding solutions to the validators, I was caching state with:

key = floor.gsub(/[^.O]/, ".").hash

but I should have had cached also the pieces used:

key = [floor.gsub(/[^.O]/, "."), hash_usage].hash

It is still remarkable that this only (in my case at least, since it is dependent on the DFS exploration order) appears to be an issue in the validators.

------

I still timeout on Butterfly and Owl Mask :/, but now I pass everything else (including ofc every validator). That is a problem.

And the code (expires in one week), in case you want to test the timings of a possible solution: https://bpa.st/HZOQ

@Rafarafa came with non-DLX solution in Ruby, so it is solvable. But there are multiple optimization steps required. Heuristics, handling symmetry, bitboarding etc. Not sure whether MEDIUM difficulty is correct bucket for this puzzle in this case.

Hmm not sure if its best idea to change testcases now. But I can move it to HARD category tho... This one was approved in a few days so I was lacking insights like yours. However @Rafarafa solved it without DLX in Ruby
Hmm so your suggestion is to make last 2 validators symmetrical maybe? Not sure whether increasing time limit would help. I know ruby, so I'll play around with your solution for a bit.

@Rafarafa It looks like your code is trying to find all the solutions? If so, that might be a reason for the timeout? My DLX solution in Python is able to solve all the cases within the time limit, without any optimisation, and it breaks out of dancing/backtracking as soon as a solution is found.

@VizGhar

I have not much experience with Solo puzzles, but it seems to me that the general consensus in I/O puzzles is that validators need to test for a similar scenario as their counterpart public tests.

The only real suggestion I had was for easier tests at the very beginning (position 2, 3), since the gap between Sample and First Aid Kit is quite noticeable. Maybe something with A, B, C to test for piece construction at the same time.

The timeout question is entirely dependent to what you have in mind for an expected solution. If you are expecting DLX, then maybe revisit the tags and call it a day. If you think it should be solvable within that time limit with some DFS, then I'm presenting you a decently optimized (not completely, it lacks at least a couple things I have in mind), that is not able to pass the last two tests.

If someone managed to solved it in python with a DFS within the 2 second limit, and you are fine with the solution they propose, they I'm fine too and I'll try to add the required optimizations.

I'll make validators more simillar to tests. That's a fair point.
I'll also add some more tests so progression is more fluent.

You have used uniq for polyomino variants; in each depth checked if there is some place that cannot be resolved and used memoization. I'd probably implement it same way... I'll try to implement my own recursive / DFS solution and then validate tags.

Thanks for inputs

I did a bit of experiment with my DLX code. I removed the code which chose which item to explore next based on MRV (minimum remaining values). Instead, I just chose the next item not yet covered in the partial solution (i.e. based on the original order in the list of items to cover). The result is that I timed out on two validators: Dino and Full Brick.

I guess a similar optimisation may be applied to a DFS approach, i.e. when deciding which piece to try next, use a heuristic such as MRV.

There is one thing I'd do differently (if i understand your solution). During backtracking you are removing only ID of used tile and then putting it back. I'd apply simmilar technique for positions (you are currently copying them)

Yeah this solution was based on @cedricdd's solution in PHP, where deleting from tables is orders of magnitude faster than in ruby.

Now in my solution when you place a tile, you remove its position from the choices but also every choice of other tiles that would overlap with the placed tile.

I don't do it but you could also, once you place a tile with, let's say, label A, remove every choice that was a symmetry of that tile in further depths. I tried that very naively and was slower. The extra checks were heavier than just iterating over impossible choices, discarded via:

next if usage[piece_type] > 0

For your reference, backtracking solution written in Python and using MRV as heuristic: https://pastebin.com/SYyC5ZKJ

(link will expire after a week)

Both my DLX and backtracking solutions pass all cases in less than 1 second, except for the last validator, where DLX takes 1.5644 second and backtracking takes 4.5 to 5 seconds (varies in various runs).
Looks like Ruby still fails last test and validator. But DFS tag was removed... I'll look at this tommorow (including your comment and mentioning your tutorial)
statement updated
Heh I removed tile shape check :facepalm: should be fixed now
Whatever is your choice, I like your puzzle and I am ready to approve it
To clarify, I just mean it's possible to fill in the board in a single turn, even if you specify that only one piece should be placed per turn. I don't have any preferences myself.
All done including stub and statement updates. Should be GTG
